question.title: Selenium not working on the server but working locally
question.body:
I am working on trying to use selenium to bypass a login with user and password. I managed to make it work locally in java using the following code (edited to eliminate sensitive information):

 
        ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions();
        options.addArguments("--headless");
        log.info("starting web driver");
        WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(options);
        final String url = props.getProperty(configuration.getUrl()).orElse("");
        driver.get(url);


        driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(1000));
        return driver;

and then


log.info("inputting the username");

       driver.findElement(By.<htmlattribute>("identifier")).sendKeys(credential.getUsername());

       driver.findElement(By.<htmlattribute>("input")).submit();

       log.info("inputting the password");

       driver.findElement(By.<htmlattribute>("credentials.passcode")).sendKeys(credential.getPassword());

       driver.findElement(By.<htmlattribute>("input")).submit();

Now I have moved on to the Docker realm to try and do the same, with a Docker file like this (again edited because it is proprietary code):

FROM <url>/standalone-chrome:4.23.1 as chrome

FROM <url>/tomcat:10-jdk17-openjdk

ENV JAVA_OPTS="-Xmx4096M -Xms4096M"
ADD target/<javaproject>-*.jar /target/<java-project>.jar


COPY --from=chrome /usr/bin/google-chrome /usr/bin/google-chrome
COPY --from=chrome /usr/bin/chromedriver /usr/bin/chromedriver


CMD java --add-opens java.base/java.lang.reflect=ALL-UNNAMED  -jar /target/*.jar  -Dlogging.level.org.openqa.selenium=DEBUG

Then in the code I set the system property for the chromedriver path



 log.info("Setting the path to the driver");
        System.setProperty("webdriver.chrome.driver", "/usr/bin/chromedriver");
        ChromeOptions options = new ChromeOptions();
        options.addArguments("--headless");
        log.info("starting web driver");
        WebDriver driver = new ChromeDriver(options);
        final String url = props.getProperty(configuration.getUrl()).orElse("");
        driver.get(url);


        driver.manage().timeouts().implicitlyWait(Duration.ofSeconds(1000));
        return driver;

And I always get the same error regardless of whether or not I add the chromedriver and google-chrome from the standalone to the Docker file system or not, and I set the "webdriver.chrome.driver" system property.

This is the error:


org.openqa.selenium.SessionNotCreatedException: Could not start a new session.
 Possible causes are invalid address of the remote server or browser start-up failure.


Caused by: org.openqa.selenium.WebDriverException: Driver server process died prematurely.

As you can see I am trying to get more info from the org.openqa.selenium logs to see if there is something that can point me in the right direction. To me it looks like I need to add something else from the selenium standalone of modify the path to the chromedriver in the code so that at runtime I can properly create my ChromeDriver. Maybe someone here has some clues.

question_comments.body: @browsermator you don't need to use --headless=new. The new headless mode has been the default/only mode for quite a while, so Just using --headless does the same thing.

it's not the driver, it's the browser.  Something's preventing it from creating a session.  You might try setting the path to the browser, and/or checking to be sure it has permissions to create the temporary directories it will be using.  You should probably also be using the new ("--headless=new"); option.  (depends on the version of Selenium methinks...)
